description:
Botrytis deweyae is a species of fungus belonging to the genus Botrytis. It is a plant pathogen that primarily infects and causes disease in the flowering plant species Dewey's sedge (Carex deweyana).

Botrytis deweyae is a filamentous, ascomycete fungus that reproduces both sexually and asexually. The fungus forms a gray, fuzzy growth on the leaves, stems, and inflorescences of the host plant. This growth consists of the fungal hyphae and conidiophores that produce numerous small, gray-brown spores called conidia.

The conidia are dispersed by wind or water and can infect healthy plant tissues, leading to necrosis, wilting, and reduced vigor in the infected Carex deweyana individuals. Botrytis deweyae can cause significant damage to Dewey's sedge populations, particularly in moist and cool environmental conditions that favor the growth and spread of the fungus.

Taxonomically, Botrytis deweyae is classified within the Ascomycota phylum, Leotiomycetes class, and Sclerotiniaceae family. It is an important pathogen to monitor and manage in areas where Dewey's sedge is present, as it can negatively impact the ecology and conservation of this plant species.
